10.1016/j.mcat.2024.114461 Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of magnetron sputter deposition of Au/Pd thin film catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 AFM images of the pure Pd (a) and 0.16 nm Au/Pd (b) thin film samples. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of Au 4f (a), comparison of Au peak shifts relative to pure Au film (b) for different 0.16 nm Au/M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) samples, XPS spectra of Au 4f (c), and Pd 3d (d) for pure Au, Pd, and Au/Pd samples. Fig 3 Fig. 4 X-ray reflectivity scans for the samples with Pd only and Pd with the thinnest layer of 0.16 nm Au. The divided reflectivity to emphasize the difference between the two reflectivity scans (a), the reflectivity scans for the Pd only (blue) and Pd with 0.16 nm Au (red) deposited with an offset for clarity (b), and the electron density profile deduced from the reflectivity fits (c). The roughness of the Pd, the roughness of the Au/Pd, and the Au thickness obtained from the fits are 0.18(1) nm, 0.28(1) nm, and 0.20(1) nm, respectively. Fig 4 Fig. 5 CVs of the prepared thin film catalysts in Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO4, Potential scan rate: 50 mV s-1. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Comparison of the ORR polarization curves of the pure Pt and different 0.16 nm Au/M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) samples (a), the ORR polarization curves of prepared thin film catalysts (b), comparison of E1/2 shifts relative to pure Au film (c), in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 at 1600 rpm, Potential scan rate: 10 mV s-1, and relationship between E1/2 shifts obtained from LSV curves and Au 4f peak shifts derived from XPS spectra relative to pure Au thin film for various 0.16 nm Au/M samples (d). Fig 6 Fig. 7 The RDE voltammograms at various rotation speeds in 0.1 M HClO4 for 0.16 nm Au/Pd sample (a), the corresponding Koutecky-Levich plots at potentials of 0.30–0.45 V (b), and Tafel plots (c) of prepared catalysts. Fig 7 Fig. 8 The ORR polarization curves of the 0.16 nm Au/Pd (a) and Pt (b) thin film catalysts with and without MeOH in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 at 1600 rpm, Potential scan rate: 10 mV s-1. Fig 8 Fig. 9 The ORR polarization curves of the 0.16 nm Au/Pd (a) and 0.16 nm Pt/Pd (b) thin film catalysts before and after durability test in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 at 1600 rpm, Potential scan rate: 10 mV s-1. Fig 9 Fig. 10 High-resolution Au 4f (a) and Pd 3d (b) XPS spectra of 0.16 nm Au/Pd sample at the initial state and after 1000 potential cycles during the durability test. The green curves belong to the metallic state (Au0 and Pd0). Fig 10 Table 1 Electrochemical properties of the prepared thin film catalysts in 0.1 M HClO4. Herein, we present the preparation of ultrathin gold (Au) films on different M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) electrodes (Au/M) using magnetron sputtering deposition for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The ORR electro-catalytic activities of prepared Au/M catalysts increase as follows: Au/Ru < Au/Ir < Au/Rh < Au/Pt < Au/Pd. Accordingly, the oxygen reduction catalytic behaviors of the Au-modified palladium (Au/Pd) thin films with various Au thicknesses (0.16, 0.24, 0.5, and 1 nm) are investigated in acidic environments. It is found that Au modifications can promote oxygen reduction performances due to the development of more catalytic active sites on the Pd catalyst through the existence of Au atoms. Noticeably, Au/Pd samples exhibit a connection in oxygen reduction ability as a function of Au thickness, with the ultrathin 0.16 nm Au/Pd being the most active ORR catalyst. Significantly, the 0.16 nm Au/Pd material demonstrates superior stability after 1000 potential cycles compared with the 0.16 nm Pt/Pd owing to the influence of Au coating and structurally stable surfaces. Therefore, surface modification with the deposition of Au films on Pd represents a favorable technique to boost both the ORR capability and stability of the electro-catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ultrathin gold film Palladium Magnetron sputtering Oxygen reduction reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is one of the most widely investigated electro-catalytical processes since this half-reaction is a major issue restricting the efficiency of fuel cell technologies [1,2]. Platinum (Pt) catalysts have been generally utilized as cathodic materials in such devices; however, their rarity and high price prohibit the broad-based industrial applications of fuel cell systems [3,4]. Hence, designing advanced non-Pt electro-catalysts for ORR is still a crucial hurdle in the development of fuel cells. Palladium (Pd), amongst the various metallic elements under scrutiny, possesses characteristics closely analogous to those of Pt while being more available and significantly less expensive [5–7] as the number of internal combustion engines decreases. Recently, the oxygen reduction on Pd and its alloyed nanocatalysts has attracted considerable interest [8,9]. Pd-based materials are the electro-catalysts with the second-best catalytic activity for ORR, behind Pt catalysts [10]. The catalytic selectivity towards the ORR process in the existence of methanol in direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) is another benefit of Pd-based catalysts [11,12]. Numerous studies have suggested that Pd-based alloys and core-shell nanostructures may have superior oxygen reduction catalytic properties compared with Pd alone, which could be associated with the adjustments of d-band position and lattice distortion [9,13,14]. Nevertheless, under operating environments of fuel cells, the 3d transitional metal constituents of cathodic catalysts may dissolve into acidic solutions. The electrochemical stability of the catalysts is just as essential for the industrialization of fuel cell systems as their catalytic activity and price. As a consequence of the leaching and aggregation of surface metallic atoms under complex electrochemical environments, the normally inert metal becomes unstable [15,16]. Earlier investigations have shown that introducing other metallic components into nanostructures can modify electronic constructions and increase stability during oxygen reduction procedures [17–19]. Gold (Au) has so far been demonstrated as a durable element that enhances the stability of Pt catalysts towards oxygen reduction as a result of its much lesser oxophilicity relative to Pt [20]. Furthermore, the deposition of foreign metallic layers onto well-organized substrates has been broadly studied in electrochemistry and surface science, aiming to make durable nanocatalysts. These systems have become fascinating for electro-catalytic processes due to their distinct attributes compared to individual elements [21,22]. For instance, the deposition of Au clusters on the surface of nanoparticulated Pt catalysts has been described to stabilize the Pt nanocatalysts against dissolution during accelerated stability tests owing to diminishing PtOH generation and consequently boosting their oxygen reduction durability [23]. Previous works conducted by several research teams have pointed out the stability enhancements of Pt materials for ORR obtained by partly covering the surface of catalysts with Au atoms through a variety of techniques [24–26]. Up to now, very few scientists have concentrated on the synergetic interaction between Au and metallic substrates to concurrently increase the electro-catalytic activity and durability of Pd-containing materials for catalyzing oxygen reduction. In the present work, the ultrathin Au films were deposited on different M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) electrode surfaces (Au/M) by the magnetron sputtering method for ORR. These Au/M samples revealed M-dependent oxygen reduction electro-catalytic abilities, with Au/Pd being the most efficient catalyst. Thereby, we developed Au-modified Pd (Au/Pd) thin film catalysts with varied Au thicknesses (0.16, 0.24, 0.5, and 1 nm) to explore their ORR electro-catalytic performances in acidic conditions. The physical analyses of prepared thin films indicated that the thickness of the Au could substantially affect the ORR electro-catalytic properties. The activities of these thin films for ORR catalysis were examined using some electrochemical measurements. Although bulk Au seems to be inactive, the coverage of the ultrathin 0.16 nm Au layer on Pd (0.16 nm Au/Pd) specified noticeably higher electro-catalytic ability towards ORR. As far as we know, no previous study has been published showing the influence of such Au coverage on Pd electrode activities for oxygen reduction in acidic media. The optimum Au-modified Pd (0.16 nm Au/Pd) catalyst exhibited similar behavior to the Pt catalyst towards ORR but more intriguingly possessed greater durability compared with the 0.16 nm Pt-modified Pd (0.16 nm Pt/Pd) sample. The augmented activity and stability of the optimum Au/Pd material can be attributed to Au modification, the synergistic interactions between the metallic components, and the unique electronic effects observed in binary thin film catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Sample fabrication Pt, Pd, Au, and Au/M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) thin films were deposited on the surface of glassy carbon (GC) electrodes using the magnetron sputtering method (Orion 8, AJA International sputtering system) from pure metal M (99,98% purity) and Au (99,98% purity) targets at room temperature. The sputtering deposition was conducted at a pressure of 3 mTorr in the Ar atmosphere with a purity of 99.999%, while the base pressure within the vacuum chamber was around 10–7 Torr. The thicknesses of the deposited pure metal films were 20 nm. The Au/M thin films were deposited in a sequential manner, with Au on top of 20 nm pure metal (M) films. The deposition rate of Au was 0.8 Å s-1 at 25 W of the discharge power. To obtain the various thicknesses of Au in Au/Pd thin films, the deposition time of Au was controlled (Fig. 1 ). To assure the repeatability of the deposition, the parameters of the preparation procedure were regulated by a computer. 2.2 Physical characterization The surface morphology of the thin films was analyzed through atomic force microscopy (AFM, Bruker, ICON). The AFM images were recorded in tapping mode using silicon tips under ambient conditions. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed by the high-resolution spectrometer SPECS PHOIBOS 100/150 using an Al anode with a power of 200 W. The pressure during measurements was 10–8 mbar. The XPS experiments were conducted at room temperature. The investigated samples were placed on a molybdenum sample holder using conductive carbon tape. The Pd and Au/Pd samples were also characterized by X-ray reflectivity scans. The X-ray measurements were carried out with a Rigaku 12 kW rotating anode X-ray generator equipped with a Huber four-circle diffractometer. A bent graphite (002) monochromator was used to select the Cu Kα fluorescence line and focus it onto the sample position at the center of the diffractometer with a focal distance of 50 cm. 2.3 Electrochemical characterization The electro-catalytic activities of prepared thin film catalysts were examined using a potentiostat (Autolab PGSTAT 302 N) coupled with a standard three-electrode electrochemical configuration. A glassy carbon electrode (GC, diameter: 6 mm) was used as the working electrode, and Pt wire and saturated Ag/AgCl (3 M NaCl) were used as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. To prevent the acid solution from chloride contamination, the reference electrode was situated in another compartment linked to the primary electrochemical cell through a salt bridge. In all experiments, ultrapure (18 MΩ cm) deionized (DI) water (Elga Purelab Ultra) was employed to make aqueous solutions. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were accomplished in 0.1 M HClO4 solutions saturated with Ar at the potential range of −0.2–1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl and the scan speed of 50 mV/s. The ORR experiments were conducted by utilizing linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) on rotating disk electrodes (RDE) in O2-purged 0.1 M HClO4 solution at 10 mV/s with different rotation electrode speeds from 400 to 2025 rpm. The accelerated durability tests were performed between 0.3 and 0.7 vs. Ag/AgCl (0.6 and 1.0 V vs. RHE) for 1000 cycles at 50 mV/s in Ar-purged 0.1 M HClO4 solution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical characterization of the samples The AFM images of pure Pd and 0.16 nm Au/Pd surfaces are illustrated in Fig. 2 . The AFM images show the smooth surface of the obtained thin films (Fig. 2a and b). As depicted in Fig. 2a, the average roughness (rq) of the Pd surface is found to be 0.181 nm. The average roughness of the 0.16 nm Au/Pd surface is estimated to be 0.244 nm (Fig. 2b), signifying a notable increase when compared to the pure Pd thin film. XPS was employed to elucidate the surface structure of pure Au and 0.16 nm Au/M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) catalysts (Fig. 3 a and b). Fig. 3a displays local Au 4f spectra of pure Au and Au-modified M catalysts. The pure Au spectrum exhibits a pair of spin-orbit doublets at a low-energy band and a high-energy band at 84 and 87.6 eV indexed as Au 4f7/2 and Au 4f5/2, respectively [27]. As presented in Fig. 3a, the Au 4f binding energies in the Au/M materials were shifted negatively compared to those in pure Au. Among these samples, the 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst displayed the highest Au peak shifts relative to pure Au film, benefiting the modification of electronic structures of Pd with Au and the formation of the Au/Pd binary catalyst (Fig. 3b). Thus, the surface composition and electronic structures of Pd, Au, and Au/Pd materials with various Au thicknesses were also analyzed by XPS measurements (Fig. 3c and d). The Au 4f spectra of these samples are shown in Fig. 3c. Remarkably, the negative shift of binding energies of the Au 4f peaks of Au/Pd samples increased by increasing the thickness of the Au layer for the as-prepared 0.5 nm Au/Pd catalyst. The decrease of the binding energies of Au for the Au/Pd materials compared to the pure Au indicates the charge transfer from Pd to Au, which can be associated with the electronic interplay between atomic orbitals of metallic elements and, therefore, the alloyed structure fabrication [27–30]. Fig. 3d shows the XPS spectra of Pd in pure Pd and Au/Pd catalysts. The pure Pd spectrum manifests two peaks at a low-energy band and a high-energy band at 335.2 and 340.5 eV that belong to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2, respectively, indicating that Pd is present predominantly in metallic form [31]. In comparison to pure Pd, there is no obvious shift of Pd 3d binding energies for the Au/Pd catalysts; nevertheless, peak shapes are slightly different, representing the changes in the composition of Au-modified samples. These findings can be explained as the modification of Pd's electronic properties by the addition of Au, in agreement with earlier studies [27,32,33]. Since the Pd films in the Au/Pd catalysts are much thicker than the Au layers and behave like bulk Pd films in contrast to the Au layers, only the top few layers of Pd are influenced by these electronic interactions. This implies that any changes in the top Pd layers caused by charge transfer between Au and Pd can be immediately compensated by the bottom Pd layers. Conversely, Au films on Pd surfaces experience more pronounced electronic effects and structural alterations due to ultrathin Au layers covering the Pd surfaces. Consequently, the fabricated Au/Pd catalysts exhibited negative shifts in Au 4f binding energies compared to the pure Au sample. The Au-induced change of the electronic structure of Pd can give rise to variations in d-band positions. In addition, the surface activity of modified Pd samples is affected by changes in d-band positions, too [10,34]. Interestingly, the XPS spectra of Au and Pd for the 0.16 nm Au/Pd sample remained unchanged after 5 CV cycles, demonstrating no alternation in the catalyst's surface (Fig. 3c and d). Accordingly, 0.16 nm Au/Pd possesses improved catalytic capability relative to that of pure Pd catalysts. The thicknesses measured with X-ray reflectivity scans were found to be consistent with the thickness of Pd and Au layers expected from the calibration of sputter deposition. In Fig. 4 b, the two reflectivity scans of the unmodified 20 nm thick Pd film (blue) and the sample modified with 0.16 nm thick Au (red) are shown. The blue and red solid lines fit the reflectivity scans, respectively. The normalized reflectivity is also displayed in Fig. 4a, demonstrating that Au 0.16 nm is thick enough to significantly modify the reflectivity. In Fig. 4c, the respective density profiles are shown, where the thickness of Au layers is clearly identified. However, the electron density of the Au film from the fit is significantly lower than that of the ideal Au density, the thickness of 0.20(1) nm from the fit is larger than 0.16 nm expected from the sputtering, and the roughness of the surface increases from 0.18(1) nm to 0.28(1) nm. These X-ray reflectivity results indicate that Au does not uniformly cover the Pd surface, resulting in a reduced Pd surface exposed to the electrolyte. These findings also agree with the AFM results discussed above. 3.2 Electrochemical characterization of the samples 3.2.1 Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and rotating disk electrode (RDE) The electrochemical behaviors of prepared thin film catalysts were assessed using cyclic voltammetry (CV) in Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 electrolytes. To compare the electro-catalytic ability, the CV of the pure Pt thin film is also presented in Fig. 5 . As can be seen in Fig. 5, the CV features for the modified Pd samples are similar to pure Pd, illustrating the regions of desorption/adsorption of hydrogen and formation/reduction of Pd oxide. The deposition of the higher thickness of Au layers considerably reduced the charge of surface oxidation/reduction for the Au-modified samples. Further analysis of the CV profiles showed that Au/Pd thin films exhibited less anodic characteristics compared to Pd within the high potential areas associated with surface oxidation. This observation clarifies that modifying Pd catalysts with ultrathin Au-sputtered layers can be directed to better tolerance to surface oxidation in oxygen reduction catalysis. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of Pd-based catalysts was estimated by measuring the Coulombic charge for PdO reduction, divided by the theoretical charge value for the reduction of PdO monolayer (424 μC cm-2) [35]. The ECSA of the Pt thin film sample was experimentally determined by integrating the charge corresponding to the hydrogen adsorption/desorption observed in the CV profile (Fig. 5), utilizing a conversion factor of 210 μC cm-2 [36]. The values of calculated ECSAs are tabulated in Table 1 . As expected, the ECSA value of Au/Pd materials decreased with the increase in the thickness of Au layers. The larger ECSA of the 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst compared to other samples with thicker layers of Au would offer a greater number of active sites for the electro-catalysis of oxygen reduction. The ORR electro-catalytic properties of all samples were evaluated in O2-purged 0.1 M HClO4 solutions. The ORR activities of 0.16 nm Au/M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) materials were examined and compared with the pure Pt thin film (Fig. 6 a). The oxygen reduction ability of 0.16 nm Au deposited on Pt, Ru, Rh, Ir, and Pd improved in the following order: Au/Ru < Au/Ir < Au/Rh < Au/Pt < Au/Pd. Hence, the ORR behaviors of Au/Pd thin films with different thicknesses of Au layers were investigated. Fig. 6b shows the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves at 1600 rpm from the rotating disk electrode (RDE) for prepared thin films. The onset potentials (Eonset) measured in 0.1 M HClO4 for the resultant thin film materials are provided in Table 1. The oxygen reduction polarization curve of 0.16 nm Au/Pd thin film material unveiled the highest Eonset (0.58 V), which was close to that of pure Pt thin film (0.60 V). It is worth noticing that on Pt and Au/Pd catalysts, the mixed kinetic-diffusion control region and the diffusion-controlled region in the oxygen reduction polarization curves can be clearly observed throughout the potential ranges from 0.7 to 0.3 V and below 0.3 V, respectively. Pure Au exhibited no electro-catalytic activity over the 0.7–0.3 V potential regime. Nevertheless, the 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst displayed much greater ORR activities compared to the pure Au sample. Moreover, it is found that the oxygen reduction ability of 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst is comparable to Pt despite the fact that Au atoms covered a portion of the Pd surface. Evidently, the ORR performance is substantially influenced by the coverage of Au on the surface of Pd catalysts. Within the mixed potential domains, the oxygen reduction activities of various electro-catalysts can be compared using the evaluation of the half-wave potential (E1/2). Among all the studied M electrodes, the optimum choice was the deposition of ultrathin Au (0.16 nm) films over the surface of Pd, which was in accordance with the XPS results. As can be seen from Fig. 6c, the E1/2 values of 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst disclosed the most pronounced shifts compared to pure Au film. The presented findings are proven by the linear relationship observed between E1/2 shifts obtained from LSV curves and Au 4f peak shifts derived from XPS spectra relative to pure Au film for the different 0.16 nm Au/M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) samples (Fig. 6d). In addition, the E1/2 values achieved from ORR polarization plots in Fig. 6b for investigated samples are compiled in Table 1. The results obviously demonstrate that the E1/2 is shifted more positively (∼28 mV) in the case of 0.16 nm Au/Pd in comparison to that acquired with the pure Pd catalyst. The superior oxygen reduction capability on 0.16 nm Au/Pd relative to that on Pd most likely originates from the alteration in electronic structures between the modified Pd thin film and the bulk Pd element [22,30,37]. The prepared samples with an Au thickness in excess of 0.16 nm exhibit negative shifts in E1/2 with a corresponding decline in the current values relative to pure Pd and Pt thin films. These observations imply that as the Au thickness is increased, the ORR electro-catalytic activities of Au/Pd catalysts diminish. This could be due to the high binding strength of the Pd catalyst surface and the oxygen-containing species. Therefore, accumulating oxygenated intermediates could inhibit the desorption of oxygen-reduction products and cause slow ORR processes. In addition, another possible aspect responsible for the lower electro-catalytic ability of these samples might be the increased amounts of Au, which significantly decreases ORR active sites [17,38]. The deposition of small amounts of Au on Pd (0.16 nm Au/Pd film) can adjust the d-band center of Pd, thereby improving oxygen reduction capability, as depicted in Fig. 6b. Besides, the charge transfer between Au and Pd can increase ORR catalytic activity. It should be pointed out that the 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst behaves similarly to the pure Pt material. The obtained outcomes denote that a sample with an Au thickness of 0.16 nm possesses excellent ORR electro-catalytic capabilities. It can be supposed that an optimal Au thickness will lead to a decrease in the generation of Pd-OH, which are identified as poisoning intermediates on the surface of Pd catalysts during oxygen reduction. In order to complete the discussion, it is essential to emphasize that the Au surfaces rarely act as active oxygen reduction catalysts in acidic circumstances [39]. This is due to the fact that Au is unable to offer adsorption positions for the formation of OH (ads) intermediates. These intermediates, which are formed by H2O dissociating at the surface of Pd in acid solutions, could poison the electro-catalyst for ORR because their existence decreases the surface-active sites for oxygen activation through oxygen bond breaking. As previously stated, the presence of Au prevents the generation of oxygenated intermediates and thereby enables Pd to function effectively in ORR catalysis procedures. Fig. 7 a illustrates the RDE polarization curves at various electrode speeds (400–2025 rpm) in O2-purged 0.1 M HClO4 solutions with a sweep speed of 10 mV s-1. The ORR kinetics can be assessed based on the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) equation [40,41]. The electron transfer number (n) involved in the oxygen reduction for the optimum 1.6 nm Au/Pd catalyst was roughly four, as indicated by the respective K-L plots, which revealed excellent linearity and parallelism within a potential ranging from 0.30 to 0.45 V (Fig. 7b). These findings manifested that oxygen reduction on 1.6 nm Au/Pd thin film follows the first order reaction kinetics and a preferential four-electron route [37]. To further examine the oxygen reduction kinetics catalyzed by investigated samples, the Tafel curves were plotted, as depicted in Fig. 7c. The Tafel slopes of prepared thin films are listed in Table 1. The resulting 0.16 nm Au/Pd showed a Tafel slope of 57 mV/dec, which is close to that of the pure Pt sample (59 mV/dec). These observations verify the highly accelerated kinetics of this catalyst in the ORR process. The methanol resistance behavior of Pd-containing nanocatalysts towards oxygen reduction is essential in DMFCs as MeOH can transfer from the anodic to the cathodic side via the membranes, poisoning the cathodic catalysts along with lessening the open circuit voltage (OCV) [12]. The ORR polarization curves of the 0.16 nm Au/Pd and pure Pt thin film catalysts were evaluated in O2-purged solutions containing 0.1 M MeOH in 0.1 M HClO4 (Fig. 8 a and b). In the presence of 0.1 M MeOH, the 0.16 nm Au/Pd sample does not display any peak of methanol oxidation, demonstrating its outstanding methanol resistance (Fig. 8a). On the other hand, under identical conditions, the pure Pt thin film catalyst illustrates an observable peak of methanol oxidation at about 0.55 V (Fig. 8b). Accordingly, it is recommended that 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalysts are an appropriate option in the systematic design of methanol-resistant cathodic materials for usage in DMFCs. 3.2.2 Accelerated durability test (ADT) Durability is a vital concern that needs to be addressed before the widespread adoption of fuel cell technologies. Thereby, an accelerated durability test (ADT) for 1000 continuous cycles at a scan rate of 50 mV/s in an Ar-purged 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte was done to examine the stability of these thin film materials. As revealed in Fig. 9 a and b, the 0.16 nm Au/Pd illustrated superior long-term durability relative to the 0.16 nm Pt/Pd over ADTs. After 1000 continuous CV cycles, the ORR polarization curve for the 0.16 nm Au/Pd manifests a negative shift of just 10 mV in E1/2 (Fig. 9a). In contrast, the ORR polarization curve for the 0.16 nm Pt/Pd exhibits a noticeable negative shift of around 30 mV in E1/2, probably attributable to the gradual leaching out of the surface Pt after 1000 CV scans during the potential cycling (Fig. 9b). Notably, the considerable degradation after ADT measurements can lead to a drastic diminution in the oxygen reduction characteristics. The above outcomes reveal that the obtained 0.16 nm Au/Pd thin film sample displays slight degradation with respect to previously reported Pt/C catalysts, which normally undergo severe carbon corrosion and consequent nanoparticle loss during durability tests [42]. It has been found by our research team that the 0.16 nm Au/Pd thin film demonstrated better durability than the conventional Pt/C catalysts reported in the literature (half-wave potential change (ΔE1/2) of about 20 mV) [43]. In addition, compared with the 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst, the ORR activity degradation of the commercial Pt black (ΔE1/2 ∼ 16 mV) and Pd black (ΔE1/2 ∼ 47 mV) was clearly more dramatic after 1000 cycles of ADT, as previously published [44]. This increased durability may be caused by the covering of unstable Pd surfaces with Au layers in the tested sample. This presents a favorable strategy for suppressing the electro-catalyst degradations without reducing the oxygen reduction capability. XPS analyses were conducted to evaluate the surface structure and electronic state changes for the 0.16 nm Au/Pd thin film before and after 1000 potential cycles of the ADT (Fig. 10 ). Interestingly, the achieved results showed no notable changes in chemical states after the durability test. As illustrated in Fig. 10a, the Au 4f XPS peaks of 0.16 nm Au/Pd thin film remain nearly unchanged after the ADT experiment. Furthermore, it can be seen in Fig. 10b that Pd exists in the metallic state (Pd0) in the initial 0.16 nm Au/Pd, and there is no obvious peak of oxidation states in the Pd 3d XPS spectra of this sample after 1000 potential cycles. These observations confirmed that Au atoms deposited on Pd are stable throughout ADT, and Pd surfaces are efficiently protected with Au. The 0.16 nm Au/Pd thin film revealed increased durability towards ORR since Au deposition on Pd could lower the binding of oxygenated intermediates on the surface and suppress Pd oxidation upon ADT. According to the XPS measurements and prior investigations on the dissolution of noble metals in acidic environments [45,46], we believe that the leaching of the surface Pd might contribute to the decreased ORR performance in the 0.16 nm Au/Pd electro-catalyst; however, this deterioration is negligible. The improved durability of the 0.16 nm Au/Pd sample aligns with the Au influence on Pt catalysts earlier published [23,26]. As depicted in Table 2 , the ORR performances of prepared samples are compared with other catalysts documented in previous studies. The superior oxygen reduction performance of the 0.16 nm Au/Pd catalyst can primarily be ascribed to the following aspects: the coverage of Au on the Pd structure efficiently adjusts the electronic configuration of Pd due to ligand (electronic) and strain (geometric) effects, resulting in a greater number of active centers free from oxygen-containing species for catalyzing oxygen reduction [19,32]. Furthermore, the Au/Pd structure would considerably remove intermediated species generated through oxidation and markedly improve tolerance to poisoning, thereby enhancing durability [47]. In the meantime, the deposition of Au can significantly modify the electronic arrangement of Pd caused by ligand and strain effects, thus giving rise to the amendment of the Pd d-band position [31,59]. This suggestion is further supported by XPS observations, which confirm the electron withdrawal from Au to Pd resulting from the downshifting of the d-band position of Pd (Fig. 3). The optimum Au/Pd sample can provide more catalytic reactive points for oxygen reduction while concurrently decreasing the ability for physisorption of oxygen and the chemisorption of oxygen-containing species produced over the electro-catalyst surface [60]. This is in accordance with earlier investigations, underlining the synergetic interactions of two metallic constituents to boost the electro-catalytic stability of the catalyst [61,33]. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the magnetron sputtering technique was used to deposit ultrathin Au films on different M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) electrode surfaces (Au/M) and investigate their catalytic performance towards ORR. Among these Au/M samples, the ultrathin Au sputtered on Pd has been found to be the most effective catalyst for oxygen reduction in acidic media. Consequently, the physical and electrochemical properties of Au-modified Pd thin films with varied Au thicknesses (0.16, 0.24, 0.5, and 1 nm) were studied in this work. The obtained results indicated that even though bulk Au serves as an ineffective and oxidation-tolerant sample, Au/Pd with ultrathin 0.16 nm Au film thickness was a remarkably active material (Eonset = 0.58 V and E1/ 2 = 0.49 V) in ORR catalysis. Besides, improved ORR durability (ΔE1/ 2 = 10 mV) was delivered by the optimum 0.16 nm Au/Pd thin film. This increased performance could be attributed to the Au modification of the Pd structures along with synergistic interplays between Pd and Au, which provide more influential catalytic active positions for ORR. The boosted electro-catalytic activity and durability in Au/Pd thin films offer a viable alternative for Pt-free, highly durable oxygen reduction materials. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we present the preparation of ultrathin gold (Au) films on different M (M = Pd, Pt, Rh, Ir, and Ru) electrodes (Au/M) using magnetron sputtering deposition for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The ORR electro-catalytic activities of prepared Au/M catalysts increase as follows: Au/Ru < Au/Ir < Au/Rh < Au/Pt < Au/Pd. Accordingly, the oxygen reduction catalytic behaviors of the Au-modified palladium (Au/Pd) thin films with various Au thicknesses (0.16, 0.24, 0.5, and 1 nm) are investigated in acidic environments. It is found that Au modifications can promote oxygen reduction performances due to the development of more catalytic active sites on the Pd catalyst through the existence of Au atoms. Noticeably, Au/Pd samples exhibit a connection in oxygen reduction ability as a function of Au thickness, with the ultrathin 0.16 nm Au/Pd being the most active ORR catalyst. Significantly, the 0.16 nm Au/Pd material demonstrates superior stability after 1000 potential cycles compared with the 0.16 nm Pt/Pd owing to the influence of Au coating and structurally stable surfaces. Therefore, surface modification with the deposition of Au films on Pd represents a favorable technique to boost both the ORR capability and stability of the electro-catalysts.
